title: Gas Migration During Static Conditions
operationalFocus: Managing pressure buildup when circulation is not possible
question: On {{wellProfile.wellName}}, you took a {{scenario.kickVolume}} bbl gas kick at {{currentSection.settingDepth.tvd}} {{currentSection.settingDepth.unit}} TVD and shut in. SIDPP is {{scenario.sidpp}} psi and SICP is {{scenario.sicp}} psi. Due to {{scenario.reason}}, you cannot circulate for at least {{scenario.waitTime}} hours. After 1 hour static, you observe SICP has increased from {{scenario.sicp}} to {{scenario.sicpAfter1hr}} psi while SIDPP remains constant. What is happening and what is your response?

explanation.phenomenon: Gas migration. The gas bubble is rising in the annulus due to buoyancy. As it rises into lower-pressure regions, it expands, displacing mud and increasing surface pressure.
explanation.sidppConstant: SIDPP remains constant because formation pressure hasn't changed and there's no gas in the drillstring.
explanation.sicpIncreasing: SICP increases as gas rises and expands in the annulus.

steps: Calculate pressure increase from gas migration: ΔP = new SICP - original SICP
Calculate volume to bleed: V = ΔP × Annular Capacity / (MW × 0.052)
Bleed mud through choke in small increments to maintain constant BHP
Allow pressure to build to predetermined increment (typically 100 psi)

answerOptions.A: Open choke and bleed all pressure increase to return SICP to original value
answerOptions.B: Keep well shut in - do not bleed anything until you can circulate
answerOptions.C: Use volumetric method - allow controlled pressure buildup then bleed calculated volumes
answerOptions.D: Open annular and let gas escape freely to surface

feedback.correct: Correct. Volumetric method allows you to maintain constant BHP while gas migrates. You allow pressure to build (which temporarily over-pressures BHP), then bleed a calculated volume which reduces BHP back to target. This controlled approach prevents both under-balance (kick expansion) and over-balance at the shoe.
feedback.A_feedback: Bleeding all pressure increase would reduce BHP and allow the kick to expand further. You'd be chasing an ever-growing influx.
feedback.B_feedback: Keeping everything shut in causes continuous pressure buildup. Eventually SICP will exceed MAASP, risking fracture at the shoe and underground blowout.
feedback.D_feedback: Never open the annular with a kick in the well. This is an uncontrolled release.

contextualTip: With MAASP at {{currentSection.maasp}} psi and SICP now at {{scenario.sicpAfter1hr}} psi, you have {{maaspMargin}} psi before reaching shoe limits. Gas will continue migrating - at approximately {{migrationRate}} ft/hr in this mud weight. You need volumetric control.
advancedNote: Volumetric requires good annular capacity data and discipline. Each bleed must be carefully calculated and measured. Pre-calculate your pressure increments and bleed volumes before you need them.
